That Nenni hid won support from many Italians who are not sympathe¬
tic to Communism and who are not even enrolled Socialists, hut who fear the
rearming of Germany under any conditions* These Italians resented what they
regarded as the abrupt way in which Nenni's proposal was cast aside hy
Aleide de Gasperi, who then was seeking to form a new government.
These hopeful Italian Socialists point out that Nenni has concrete
proof that detaching himself even a short distance from the Communists pays
off at the polls. Immediately after World War II, the Socialists were the
biggest party in Italy. But during the period of their alliance with the
Communists, their strength diminished to the point where they were only a
substantial tall to the Communist kite. In the Chamber of Deputies after
the 1948 election, they held only 50 seats to 133 for the Reds.
For this year's election campaign, the Nenni Socialists decided
to campaign with a separate list of candidates, rather than the common
slate they drew with the Communists five years ago. Nenni's campaign slogan
was “the Socialist alternative," the clear implication being that his party
would steer a course midway between that of the Communists on the left and
the Christian Democrats in the middle. Nenni said glibly that his party
really sought only "neutrality" for Italy between the two great power blocs,
headed by the United States and Russia.
The result of this appeal has already been noted: An Increase of
50 per cent in the Nenni party*s representation in the Chamber.
But the hard fact is that Norm! at no time hasoffered to break his
so-called “unity of action" pact with the Communists. Another fact is that
if Nenni has been hinting at a revival of the Popular Front kind of govern¬
ment, so have the Communists. Communist party leader Palmiro Togliatti is
said to have told the British left-wing Labor!te, R. H. 3. Crossman, in
effect: “If Nenni goes to the right. I’ll go even further right than he
does." Togliatti's meaning was clear. And the Communists have been trying
to implement Popular Front strategy on the Italian l&borfront already in a
way I will examine in a few minutes*
And so, the effort to detach Nenni himself from the grasp of the
Communists seems to be getting nowhere* Giuseppe Saragat of the Social
Democrats, who made an effort to persuade De Gasperi to take Nenni into the
post-election cabinet under certain conditions last summer, now has given
up that angle* But Saragat still is trying, with his Social Democratic
party, to maintain what he calls "Apertura a Sinistra’* — an opening to the
left — which is designed to capture many of Nenni*s followers, if not the
head man himself.
The Saragat effort will be examined in a later Letter. It will
suffice for now to say that the available evidence indicates that the Social
Democratic leader is having no major success* But the idea of detaching
Nenni and his followers from Togliatti! the idea of bringing into the
government a unified, powerful Socialist party whose leaders had broken
decisively from the Communist embrace — that idea will continue to fas¬
cinate Italian democrats of the political left*
But an outsider taking a look at recent election results and
bits of additional evidence wonders if the reverse process isn’t the more
powerful one. I noted in a Rome newspaper yesterday that the directors of
the Nenni party had voted unanimously to accept back into the fold the Hon.
Umberto Calosso. The account said Signor Calosso had left the party in
1947, together with the Hon. Saragat.
